Posts.Content: janetweiss wrote: I have appointments this week with two breast surgeons, but I only have one set of slides from my stereotactic and core biopsies.  I know that each surgeon will want the pathologist at his/her hospital to examine the slides, but I did not want to delay my appointments.  I was going to choose between these two doctors, both of whom have excellent recommendations, depending on my level of comfort with each one.  Should I just give the slides to the doctor I choose, or should I have another set of slides made(3 days) to see if the diagnosis is the same at both places?  One is New York Hospital; the other is Memorial Sloan Kettering.    Thanks.  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: janetweiss wrote: I picked up all of my medical records from the radiologist on Friday, and I read the pathologist's report from my biopsies, in preparation for  my first surgery consultation tomorrow morning.  I was surprised that when the radiologist reviewed the findings with me, she didn't mention the fact that the calcification was high grade, with necrosis.  After doing some research, I am much more concerned than I was when I got the initial diagnosis. I want to ask the right questions.  My very crude internet research leads me to believe that something's that's high grade(don't really know what that means), with necrosis, has more of a tendency to spread.  The area is about 2 cm.  Any words of advice or experience with a similar diagnosis?  Thanks.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pathology report says DCIS is high grade, with necrosis janetweiss Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 07:29AM janetweiss wrote: Thanks, Bessie.  I posted something and would love your feedback.  I saw two doctors in New York, both of whom are excellent and top rated in Castle Connelly.  Dr. Heerdt at Sloan Kettering would not do a SNB--she said it wouldn't be necessary, since DCIS is always just that, in situ.  She would definitely do radiation after(this all depends on getting clean margins, of course).  Dr. Swistel and New York Hospital would do a SNB and depending on what he finds in there(the tumor might be quite small, since the larger area that was seen with my MRI might have just been trauma from the biopsies).  I'm no expert, but I think that even if it was tiny, I would always be worried if I didn't do radiation.  So I'm kind of stuck here and not sure which one to use.  I want to make a decision, and be done.
